note.p: This is a letter from James P. Farrell M.P for North Longford, Thomas Francis Smyth M.P. for South Leitrim, Francis Meehan M.P. for North Leitrim, Patrick Crumley M.P. for South Fermanagh and John Phillips M.P. for South Longford written on 7 April 1916. They are addressing Augustine Birrell (1850-1933), chief secretary for Ireland. The five MPs are appealing for Birrell to appoint a Mr Thomas W. Delaney to the office of chief Crown solicitor of Ireland. The position had become vacant following the sudden death of Sir Malachy Kelly on 25 March 1916. They claim that Delaney "is best entitled to the office".

text.body:
April 7. 1916 To the Right Hon A Birrell M.P.
Chief Secretary for Ireland.
Dear Mr Birrell
We the undersigned members of
Parliament respectfully appeal to you
to appoint Mr Thomas W. Delaney
Crown Solicitor of Longford to the vacant
office of Chief Crown Solicitor of Ireland vacant
by the death of Sir Malachy Kelly.
We support Mr Delanys application
solely on the question of merit. He is
well known in the midlands of Ireland
to be a solicitor of Commanding ability
and force of character. He is well
known as a public man in Co.and
district councils and has rendered inestimable
service to the cause of recruiting in Ireland.
We therefore urge by claims on the
ground of personal merit and public service
& on these grounds we believe he as
a Crown solicitor with practical knowledge
of the work is best entitled to the office
Signed James P. Farrell M.P. North Longford
Thos. F. Smyth M.P. South Leitrim
Francis E. Meehan M.P. N Leitrim
P Crumley M.P. S Fermanagh
John Phillips M.P. S Longford
